Interpretation: Reflects average blood glucose over 2–3 months. Higher values suggest chronic hyperglycemia and increased diabetes risk.

Reference Range: Normal: <1 mg/L | Low-grade inflammation: 1–3 mg/L | High: >3 mg/L
Interpretation: CRP rises with age. Elevated levels indicate inflammation, infection, or cardiovascular risk.
PSA increases with age. Elevated values may suggest prostate enlargement, inflammation, or cancer.

Reference Range: Infants: 25–200 ng/mL | Children: 7–140 ng/mL | Adult Men: 30–400 ng/mL | Adult Women: 15–150 ng/mL
Interpretation: Low levels indicate iron deficiency or anemia. High levels may reflect inflammation, iron overload, or liver disease.
Highly specific cardiac biomarker. Elevated levels are indicative of myocardial injury or infarction.

Reference Range: Deficiency: <20 ng/mL | Insufficiency: 20–30 ng/mL | Optimal: 30–100 ng/mL | Toxic: >100 ng/mL
Interpretation: Regulates calcium metabolism and bone health. Elderly more prone to deficiency due to reduced synthesis and absorption.
